htmlEmbed:
Covid: Did Pfizer's boss cast doubt on his own vaccine?By Rachel Schraer0/19/2022

Inaccurate posts about the Pfizer vaccine's protection against Omicron took the drug company's boss out of context.

Reality CheckRead

Check</a></li></ul></div></div></div></header><div data-component="image-block" class="ssrcss-vk3nhx-ComponentWrapper e1xue1i810"><figure class="ssrcss-wpgbih-StyledFigure e34k3c23"><div class="ssrcss-ab5fd8-StyledFigureContainer e34k3c21"><span class="ssrcss-11kpz0x-Placeholder e16icw910"><span><noscript><img alt="Albert Bourla, Pfizer CEO" srcSet="https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/240/cpsprodpb/1149C/production/_122721807_gettyimages-1192138649.jpg 240w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/320/cpsprodpb/1149C/production/_122721807_gettyimages-1192138649.jpg 320w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/480/cpsprodpb/1149C/production/_122721807_gettyimages-1192138649.jpg 480w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/624/cpsprodpb/1149C/production/_122721807_gettyimages-1192138649.jpg 624w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/800/cpsprodpb/1149C/production/_122721807_gettyimages-1192138649.jpg 800w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/976/cpsprodpb/1149C/production/_122721807_gettyimages-1192138649.jpg 976w" src="https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/976/cpsprodpb/1149C/production/_122721807_gettyimages-1192138649.jpg" width="976" height="549" loading="lazy" class="ssrcss-1drmwog-Image ee0ct7c0"/></noscript></span></span><span role="text" class="ssrcss-1hn5d7b-StyledFigureCopyright e34k3c20"><span class="visually-hidden ssrcss-1f39n02-VisuallyHidden e1y6uwnp0">Image source, </span>Getty Images</span></div><figcaption class="ssrcss-name08-StyledFigureCaption e34k3c22"><span class="visually-hidden ssrcss-1f39n02-VisuallyHidden e1y6uwnp0">Image caption, </span><div spacing="6" class="ssrcss-y7krbn-Stack e1y4nx260">Comments by Pfizer's boss, Albert Bourla, have led to confusion</div></figcaption></figure></div><div data-component="text-block" class="ssrcss-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i86"><div class="ssrcss-7uxr49-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi1"><p class="ssrcss-1q0x1qg-Paragraph eq5iqo00"><b class="ssrcss-hmf8ql-BoldText e5tfeyi3">"I've never doubted Covid-19 vaccination... until now."</b></p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="ssrcss-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i86"><div class="ssrcss-7uxr49-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi1"><p class="ssrcss-1q0x1qg-Paragraph eq5iqo00">Jerome doesn't follow news closely on Twitter, using the site mainly to tweet about sports and books he's enjoying. </p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="ssrcss-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i86"><div class="ssrcss-7uxr49-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi1"><p class="ssrcss-1q0x1qg-Paragraph eq5iqo00">The 41-year-old bus driver, from Quebec has mostly supported local Covid restrictions, although he admits to growing "fed up", two years into the pandemic. </p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="ssrcss-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i86"><div class="ssrcss-7uxr49-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi1"><p class="ssrcss-1q0x1qg-Paragraph eq5iqo00">His feed reveals him mildly grumbling about his children's home-schooling, among posts about favourite authors and Canada's national football team. </p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="ssrcss-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i86"><div class="ssrcss-7uxr49-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi1"><p class="ssrcss-1q0x1qg-Paragraph eq5iqo00">But casually scrolling on the social-media site, one Monday early in the new year, he came across a video clip appearing to show the head of Pfizer suggesting his vaccine provided no protection at all against Omicron.</p></div></div><div data-component="subheadline-block" class="ssrcss-dm4ypg-ComponentWrapper-HeadlineComponentWrapper e1xue1i89"><h2 tabindex="-1" id="Severe-disease" class="ssrcss-y2fd7s-StyledHeading e1fj1fc10"><span role="text">Severe disease</span></h2></div><div data-component="text-block" class="ssrcss-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i86"><div class="ssrcss-7uxr49-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi1"><p class="ssrcss-1q0x1qg-Paragraph eq5iqo00">Albert Bourla could be seen saying: "We know that the two doses of the vaccine offer very limited protection, if any." </p></div></div><div id="piano-inline1"></div><div data-component="text-block" class="ssrcss-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i86"><div class="ssrcss-7uxr49-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi1"><p class="ssrcss-1q0x1qg-Paragraph eq5iqo00">Jerome tweeted: "If this video is legit, it has to sound off some alarms somewhere, no?"  </p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="ssrcss-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i86"><div class="ssrcss-7uxr49-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi1"><p class="ssrcss-1q0x1qg-Paragraph eq5iqo00">But the clip had been taken out of context from a longer interview, with Yahoo Finance, in which Mr Bourla had been discussing high infection rates with Omicron. </p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="ssrcss-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i86"><div class="ssrcss-7uxr49-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi1"><p class="ssrcss-1q0x1qg-Paragraph eq5iqo00">A Pfizer representative clarified he had been <a href="https://www.pfizer.com/news/press-release/press-release-detail/pfizer-and-biontech-provide-update-omicron-variant" class="ssrcss-1gfaiii-InlineLink e1no5rhv0">referring to research suggesting</a> while "two doses of [Pfizer-BioNTech's Covid vaccine] may not be sufficient to protect against infection with the Omicron variant", vaccinated people were thought to still be protected against severe disease. </p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="ssrcss-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i86"><div class="ssrcss-7uxr49-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi1"><p class="ssrcss-1q0x1qg-Paragraph eq5iqo00">Several studies suggest vaccines, even when they do not protect against infection, lessen the impact of the Omicron variant, first identified in South Africa, and significantly reduce the chances of ending up in hospital or dying. </p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="ssrcss-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i86"><div class="ssrcss-7uxr49-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi1"><p class="ssrcss-1q0x1qg-Paragraph eq5iqo00">Jerome told BBC News he was generally wary of things he saw online, and on looking into the video further had realised the clip was a "small part of the whole interview".</p></div></div><div data-component="unordered-list-block" class="ssrcss-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i86"><div class="ssrcss-7uxr49-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi1"><div class="ssrcss-1o5f7ft-BulletListContainer e5tfeyi0"><ul role="list"><li><a href="https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/blogs-trending-51967889" class="ssrcss-1gfaiii-InlineLink e1no5rhv0">Seven ways to stop bad information</a></li><li><a href="https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/59929638" class="ssrcss-1gfaiii-InlineLink e1no5rhv0">Does this doctor's claim about vaccines and transmission stack up?</a></li></ul></div></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="ssrcss-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i86"><div class="ssrcss-7uxr49-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi1"><p class="ssrcss-1q0x1qg-Paragraph eq5iqo00">"It was clear to me that small clip probably shouldn't be taken into account to shape my conclusion," he said.</p></div></div><div id="piano-inline2"></div><div data-component="text-block" class="ssrcss-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i86"><div class="ssrcss-7uxr49-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi1"><p class="ssrcss-1q0x1qg-Paragraph eq5iqo00">But he had "almost slipped into being manipulated". </p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="ssrcss-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i86"><div class="ssrcss-7uxr49-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi1"><p class="ssrcss-1q0x1qg-Paragraph eq5iqo00">"I was really surprised and shocked, you know, I just almost couldn't believe what I was hearing," Jerome said.</p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="ssrcss-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i86"><div class="ssrcss-7uxr49-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi1"><p class="ssrcss-1q0x1qg-Paragraph eq5iqo00">And from that brief window during which he'd expressed doubts about vaccination, his account was flooded with comments from people he characterised as the "anti-vax community".</p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="ssrcss-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i86"><div class="ssrcss-7uxr49-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi1"><p class="ssrcss-1q0x1qg-Paragraph eq5iqo00">"I have never had so many notifications on my Twitter," he said.</p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="ssrcss-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i86"><div class="ssrcss-7uxr49-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi1"><p class="ssrcss-1q0x1qg-Paragraph eq5iqo00">"People were telling me things like, 'Oh, well, you know, it's about time you wake up.'"</p></div></div><div data-component="image-block" class="ssrcss-18mjolk-ComponentWrapper e1xue1i810"><figure class="ssrcss-wpgbih-StyledFigure e34k3c23"><div class="ssrcss-ab5fd8-StyledFigureContainer e34k3c21"><span class="ssrcss-pfpsqa-Placeholder e16icw910"><span><noscript><img alt="A tweet reading: "Pfizer CEO: two doses of the vaccine offers very little protection if any. 3 doses with a booster offer reasonable protection against hospitalization and deaths. Less protection against infection." @US_FDA come get your boy!. Jerome responded below: I've never doubted Covid19 vaccination...until now. If this video is legit it has to sound off some alarms somewhere no?. The tweets are labelled 'missing context'" srcSet="https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/240/cpsprodpb/7954/production/_122906013_jerome2capture_976x976_grey-nc.png 240w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/320/cpsprodpb/7954/production/_122906013_jerome2capture_976x976_grey-nc.png 320w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/480/cpsprodpb/7954/production/_122906013_jerome2capture_976x976_grey-nc.png 480w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/624/cpsprodpb/7954/production/_122906013_jerome2capture_976x976_grey-nc.png 624w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/800/cpsprodpb/7954/production/_122906013_jerome2capture_976x976_grey-nc.png 800w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/976/cpsprodpb/7954/production/_122906013_jerome2capture_976x976_grey-nc.png 976w" src="https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/976/cpsprodpb/7954/production/_122906013_jerome2capture_976x976_grey-nc.png" width="976" height="976" loading="lazy" class="ssrcss-1drmwog-Image ee0ct7c0"/></noscript></span></span></div></figure></div><div data-component="subheadline-block" class="ssrcss-dm4ypg-ComponentWrapper-HeadlineComponentWrapper e1xue1i89"><h2 tabindex="-1" id="Big-leaps" class="ssrcss-y2fd7s-StyledHeading e1fj1fc10"><span role="text">Big leaps</span></h2></div><div data-component="text-block" class="ssrcss-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i86"><div class="ssrcss-7uxr49-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi1"><p class="ssrcss-1q0x1qg-Paragraph eq5iqo00">Jerome was also sent countless links to further misinformation, claiming "unbelievable side-effects from the vaccines".</p></div></div><div id="piano-inline3"></div><div data-component="text-block" class="ssrcss-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i86"><div class="ssrcss-7uxr49-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi1"><p class="ssrcss-1q0x1qg-Paragraph eq5iqo00">As is common online, people were taking valid points - the vaccine isn't very good at protecting against catching Omicron or it comes with a very small risk of extremely rare side-effects - and making big leaps to much stronger claims - the vaccine is unsafe or completely ineffective - not supported by the evidence.</p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="ssrcss-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i86"><div class="ssrcss-7uxr49-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi1"><p class="ssrcss-1q0x1qg-Paragraph eq5iqo00">Posts also left out crucial information - in vaccinated populations people have much milder infections or the virus itself comes with much greater risk than the vaccine of side-effects, including blood clotting, heart inflammation and death. </p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="ssrcss-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i86"><div class="ssrcss-7uxr49-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi1"><p class="ssrcss-1q0x1qg-Paragraph eq5iqo00">Many posts also made promises of fellowship and community, calling him "brother". Jerome describes himself as living a happy and contented life - but can see how someone seeking "that sense of belonging" could be more easily swayed.</p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="ssrcss-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i86"><div class="ssrcss-7uxr49-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi1"><p class="ssrcss-1q0x1qg-Paragraph eq5iqo00">"It made me realise how easily people are manipulated through false sources of information," he said. </p></div></div><div data-component="subheadline-block" class="ssrcss-dm4ypg-ComponentWrapper-HeadlineComponentWrapper e1xue1i89"><h2 tabindex="-1" id="Cast-doubt" class="ssrcss-y2fd7s-StyledHeading e1fj1fc10"><span role="text">Cast doubt</span></h2></div><div data-component="text-block" class="ssrcss-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i86"><div class="ssrcss-7uxr49-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi1"><p class="ssrcss-1q0x1qg-Paragraph eq5iqo00">In an online newsletter, writer Jordan Schachtel quoted part of Mr Bourla's comments to imply two doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine now offered only "very limited protection, if any" against Covid-19.</p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="ssrcss-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i86"><div class="ssrcss-7uxr49-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi1"><p class="ssrcss-1q0x1qg-Paragraph eq5iqo00">The tweet Jerome initially saw casting doubt on the vaccine, appears to have referenced this newsletter.</p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="ssrcss-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i86"><div class="ssrcss-7uxr49-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi1"><p class="ssrcss-1q0x1qg-Paragraph eq5iqo00">Other social-media posts, videos and podcasts also directly referenced Mr Schachtel's newsletter but took it further, suggesting Mr Bourla's comments cast doubt on whether the vaccine was "safe and effective".</p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="ssrcss-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i86"><div class="ssrcss-7uxr49-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi1"><p class="ssrcss-1q0x1qg-Paragraph eq5iqo00">Several posts also referred to unrelated comments by Mr Bourla, on the US news channel CNBC, that vaccines "don't have the safety profile that we hope we can achieve with [mRNA] technology". </p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="ssrcss-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i86"><div class="ssrcss-7uxr49-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi1"><p class="ssrcss-1q0x1qg-Paragraph eq5iqo00">However, on this occasion, he had not been talking about Covid vaccines at all.</p></div></div><div data-component="subheadline-block" class="ssrcss-dm4ypg-ComponentWrapper-HeadlineComponentWrapper e1xue1i89"><h2 tabindex="-1" id="Zero-protection" class="ssrcss-y2fd7s-StyledHeading e1fj1fc10"><span role="text">'Zero' protection</span></h2></div><div data-component="text-block" class="ssrcss-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i86"><div class="ssrcss-7uxr49-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi1"><p class="ssrcss-1q0x1qg-Paragraph eq5iqo00">A full <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2022/01/10/first-on-cnbc-cnbc-transcript-pfizer-chairman-and-ceo-albert-bourla-speaks-with-cnbcs-squawk-box-today.html" class="ssrcss-1gfaiii-InlineLink e1no5rhv0">transcript of the interview clearly shows</a> Mr Bourla was talking about another vaccine - against the shingles virus - Pfizer plans to update.</p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="ssrcss-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i86"><div class="ssrcss-7uxr49-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi1"><p class="ssrcss-1q0x1qg-Paragraph eq5iqo00">Mr Schachtel's newsletter initially made this mistake and later corrected it - but not before these comments had been picked up by former US congressman Ron Paul, who has a large social-media following.</p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="ssrcss-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i86"><div class="ssrcss-7uxr49-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi1"><p class="ssrcss-1q0x1qg-Paragraph eq5iqo00">In a YouTube video, Mr Paul explicitly referenced Mr Schachtel's newsletter when he repeated claims Mr Bourla had said the Covid vaccine was not safe and provided no protection against Omicron. </p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="ssrcss-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i86"><div class="ssrcss-7uxr49-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi1"><p class="ssrcss-1q0x1qg-Paragraph eq5iqo00">Claims Pfizer had "admitted... current vaccines 'do not work'" or "offer 'zero' protection against Covid-19", linking to Mr Paul's YouTube clip, then spread across numerous online platforms.</p></div></div><div data-component="image-block" class="ssrcss-18mjolk-ComponentWrapper e1xue1i810"><figure class="ssrcss-wpgbih-StyledFigure class="ssrcss-dm4ypg-ComponentWrapper-HeadlineComponentWrapper e1xue1i89"><h2 tabindex="-1" id="Fewer-deaths" class="ssrcss-y2fd7s-StyledHeading e1fj1fc10"><span role="text">Fewer deaths</span></h2></div><div data-component="text-block" class="ssrcss-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i86"><div class="ssrcss-7uxr49-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi1"><p class="ssrcss-1q0x1qg-Paragraph eq5iqo00">Research by independent scientists and public health experts has shown the positive impact vaccinations are having in preventing serious illness - <a href="https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-59696499" class="ssrcss-1gfaiii-InlineLink e1no5rhv0">particularly against the Omicron variant</a>.</p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="ssrcss-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i86"><div class="ssrcss-7uxr49-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi1"><p class="ssrcss-1q0x1qg-Paragraph eq5iqo00">One study suggests people three months after a second vaccine dose are 70% less likely to develop severe disease from an Omicron infection, dropping to 50% after six months.</p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="ssrcss-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i86"><div class="ssrcss-7uxr49-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi1"><p class="ssrcss-1q0x1qg-Paragraph eq5iqo00">Another has found double-vaccinated people are 65% less likely to be admitted to hospital with Omicron than those unvaccinated. </p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="ssrcss-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i86"><div class="ssrcss-7uxr49-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi1"><p class="ssrcss-1q0x1qg-Paragraph eq5iqo00">Also, many countries with high rates of vaccination have been experiencing very high Covid infection levels but far fewer deaths than during previous peaks.</p></div></div><div data-component="image-block" class="ssrcss-18mjolk-ComponentWrapper e1xue1i810"><figure class="ssrcss-wpgbih-StyledFigure readabilityObject.title: Covid: Did Pfizer's boss cast doubt on his own vaccine?
readabilityObject.content:
By Rachel Schraer
Health and disinformation reporter

"I've never doubted Covid-19 vaccination... until now."

Jerome doesn't follow news closely on Twitter, using the site mainly to tweet about sports and books he's enjoying.

The 41-year-old bus driver, from Quebec has mostly supported local Covid restrictions, although he admits to growing "fed up", two years into the pandemic.

His feed reveals him mildly grumbling about his children's home-schooling, among posts about favourite authors and Canada's national football team.

But casually scrolling on the social-media site, one Monday early in the new year, he came across a video clip appearing to show the head of Pfizer suggesting his vaccine provided no protection at all against Omicron.

Severe disease

Albert Bourla could be seen saying: "We know that the two doses of the vaccine offer very limited protection, if any."

Jerome tweeted: "If this video is legit, it has to sound off some alarms somewhere, no?"

But the clip had been taken out of context from a longer interview, with Yahoo Finance, in which Mr Bourla had been discussing high infection rates with Omicron.

A Pfizer representative clarified he had been referring to research suggesting while "two doses of [Pfizer-BioNTech's Covid vaccine] may not be sufficient to protect against infection with the Omicron variant", vaccinated people were thought to still be protected against severe disease.

Several studies suggest vaccines, even when they do not protect against infection, lessen the impact of the Omicron variant, first identified in South Africa, and significantly reduce the chances of ending up in hospital or dying.

Jerome told BBC News he was generally wary of things he saw online, and on looking into the video further had realised the clip was a "small part of the whole interview".

"It was clear to me that small clip probably shouldn't be taken into account to shape my conclusion," he said.

But he had "almost slipped into being manipulated".

"I was really surprised and shocked, you know, I just almost couldn't believe what I was hearing," Jerome said.

And from that brief window during which he'd expressed doubts about vaccination, his account was flooded with comments from people he characterised as the "anti-vax community".

"I have never had so many notifications on my Twitter," he said.

"People were telling me things like, 'Oh, well, you know, it's about time you wake up.'"

Big leaps

Jerome was also sent countless links to further misinformation, claiming "unbelievable side-effects from the vaccines".

As is common online, people were taking valid points - the vaccine isn't very good at protecting against catching Omicron or it comes with a very small risk of extremely rare side-effects - and making big leaps to much stronger claims - the vaccine is unsafe or completely ineffective - not supported by the evidence.

Posts also left out crucial information - in vaccinated populations people have much milder infections or the virus itself comes with much greater risk than the vaccine of side-effects, including blood clotting, heart inflammation and death.

Many posts also made promises of fellowship and community, calling him "brother". Jerome describes himself as living a happy and contented life - but can see how someone seeking "that sense of belonging" could be more easily swayed.

"It made me realise how easily people are manipulated through false sources of information," he said.

Cast doubt

In an online newsletter, writer Jordan Schachtel quoted part of Mr Bourla's comments to imply two doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine now offered only "very limited protection, if any" against Covid-19.

The tweet Jerome initially saw casting doubt on the vaccine, appears to have referenced this newsletter.

Other social-media posts, videos and podcasts also directly referenced Mr Schachtel's newsletter but took it further, suggesting Mr Bourla's comments cast doubt on whether the vaccine was "safe and effective".

Several posts also referred to unrelated comments by Mr Bourla, on the US news channel CNBC, that vaccines "don't have the safety profile that we hope we can achieve with [mRNA] technology".

However, on this occasion, he had not been talking about Covid vaccines at all.

'Zero' protection

A full transcript of the interview clearly shows Mr Bourla was talking about another vaccine - against the shingles virus - Pfizer plans to update.

Mr Schachtel's newsletter initially made this mistake and later corrected it - but not before these comments had been picked up by former US congressman Ron Paul, who has a large social-media following.

In a YouTube video, Mr Paul explicitly referenced Mr Schachtel's newsletter when he repeated claims Mr Bourla had said the Covid vaccine was not safe and provided no protection against Omicron.

Claims Pfizer had "admitted... current vaccines 'do not work'" or "offer 'zero' protection against Covid-19", linking to Mr Paul's YouTube clip, then spread across numerous online platforms.

Fewer deaths

Research by independent scientists and public health experts has shown the positive impact vaccinations are having in preventing serious illness - particularly against the Omicron variant.

One study suggests people three months after a second vaccine dose are 70% less likely to develop severe disease from an Omicron infection, dropping to 50% after six months.

Another has found double-vaccinated people are 65% less likely to be admitted to hospital with Omicron than those unvaccinated.

Also, many countries with high rates of vaccination have been experiencing very high Covid infection levels but far fewer deaths than during previous peaks.
readabilityObject.textContent: By Rachel SchraerHealth and disinformation reporterImage source, Getty ImagesImage caption, Comments by Pfizer's boss, Albert Bourla, have led to confusion"I've never doubted Covid-19 vaccination... until now."Jerome doesn't follow news closely on Twitter, using the site mainly to tweet about sports and books he's enjoying. The 41-year-old bus driver, from Quebec has mostly supported local Covid restrictions, although he admits to growing "fed up", two years into the pandemic. His feed reveals him mildly grumbling about his children's home-schooling, among posts about favourite authors and Canada's national football team. But casually scrolling on the social-media site, one Monday early in the new year, he came across a video clip appearing to show the head of Pfizer suggesting his vaccine provided no protection at all against Omicron.Severe diseaseAlbert Bourla could be seen saying: "We know that the two doses of the vaccine offer very limited protection, if any." Jerome tweeted: "If this video is legit, it has to sound off some alarms somewhere, no?"  But the clip had been taken out of context from a longer interview, with Yahoo Finance, in which Mr Bourla had been discussing high infection rates with Omicron. A Pfizer representative clarified he had been referring to research suggesting while "two doses of [Pfizer-BioNTech's Covid vaccine] may not be sufficient to protect against infection with the Omicron variant", vaccinated people were thought to still be protected against severe disease. Several studies suggest vaccines, even when they do not protect against infection, lessen the impact of the Omicron variant, first identified in South Africa, and significantly reduce the chances of ending up in hospital or dying. Jerome told BBC News he was generally wary of things he saw online, and on looking into the video further had realised the clip was a "small part of the whole interview"."It was clear to me that small clip probably shouldn't be taken into account to shape my conclusion," he said.But he had "almost slipped into being manipulated". "I was really surprised and shocked, you know, I just almost couldn't believe what I was hearing," Jerome said.And from that brief window during which he'd expressed doubts about vaccination, his account was flooded with comments from people he characterised as the "anti-vax community"."I have never had so many notifications on my Twitter," he said."People were telling me things like, 'Oh, well, you know, it's about time you wake up.'"Big leapsJerome was also sent countless links to further misinformation, claiming "unbelievable side-effects from the vaccines".As is common online, people were taking valid points - the vaccine isn't very good at protecting against catching Omicron or it comes with a very small risk of extremely rare side-effects - and making big leaps to much stronger claims - the vaccine is unsafe or completely ineffective - not supported by the evidence.Posts also left out crucial information - in vaccinated populations people have much milder infections or the virus itself comes with much greater risk than the vaccine of side-effects, including blood clotting, heart inflammation and death. Many posts also made promises of fellowship and community, calling him "brother". Jerome describes himself as living a happy and contented life - but can see how someone seeking "that sense of belonging" could be more easily swayed."It made me realise how easily people are manipulated through false sources of information," he said. Cast doubtIn an online newsletter, writer Jordan Schachtel quoted part of Mr Bourla's comments to imply two doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine now offered only "very limited protection, if any" against Covid-19.The tweet Jerome initially saw casting doubt on the vaccine, appears to have referenced this newsletter.Other social-media posts, videos and podcasts also directly referenced Mr Schachtel's newsletter but took it further, suggesting Mr Bourla's comments cast doubt on whether the vaccine was "safe and effective".Several posts also referred to unrelated comments by Mr Bourla, on the US news channel CNBC, that vaccines "don't have the safety profile that we hope we can achieve with [mRNA] technology". However, on this occasion, he had not been talking about Covid vaccines at all.'Zero' protectionA full transcript of the interview clearly shows Mr Bourla was talking about another vaccine - against the shingles virus - Pfizer plans to update.Mr Schachtel's newsletter initially made this mistake and later corrected it - but not before these comments had been picked up by former US congressman Ron Paul, who has a large social-media following.In a YouTube video, Mr Paul explicitly referenced Mr Schachtel's newsletter when he repeated claims Mr Bourla had said the Covid vaccine was not safe and provided no protection against Omicron. Claims Pfizer had "admitted... current vaccines 'do not work'" or "offer 'zero' protection against Covid-19", linking to Mr Paul's YouTube clip, then spread across numerous online platforms.Image caption, Ron Paul's YouTube channel has around 300,000 subscribersFewer deathsResearch by independent scientists and public health experts has shown the positive impact vaccinations are having in preventing serious illness - particularly against the Omicron variant.One study suggests people three months after a second vaccine dose are 70% less likely to develop severe disease from an Omicron infection, dropping to 50% after six months.Another has found double-vaccinated people are 65% less likely to be admitted to hospital with Omicron than those unvaccinated. Also, many countries with high rates of vaccination have been experiencing very high Covid infection levels but far fewer deaths than during previous peaks.
